FEVER CASES CONCEALED.

Former Cuban Administration Ac-
cused by Gen. Wood of Covering
Up Facts.
[Special Dispatch to The Evening Post.]

WASHINGTON, October 23.--Gen. Wood has
been questioned on all sides about the yel-
low-fever epidemic in Havana. The figures
for September of this year appear to ex-
ceed the figures of either 1898 or 1899, and
the inference is drawn from this that the
fever has done more damage and is making
a worse spread now than heretofore. Gen.
Wood denies this. He says that the assump-
tion is founded on the mistaken idea that
the statistics were given out last year as
freely as they are this year. They are now
given to all the papers daily as freely as
any other news; indeed, it is the effort of
the existing Government in Cuba to keep
the public informed candidly on all subjects
in which it takes a legitimate interest.

The inference from Gen. Wood's words
bears rather severely upon the regime of
Gen. Brooke. As Governor-General, Gen.
Brooke was never particularly fond of giv-
ing information to the press, but this is the
first intimation made in any authoritative
quarter that he made a practice of con-
cealing sanitary statistics.

Gen. Wood says further that the idea that
Havana was well cleaned up a year ago is
an error.

The New York Sun of this morning prints
in a dispatch from Washington an interview
with Gen. Wood. In the course of his re-
marks, as reported, he specifically accuses
the Administration of last year of giving
out false returns in regard to the number
of cases of yellow fever. He is reported as
saying:

There is nothing new in the yellow-fever
epidemic. It is not as large as last year, but
the difference is that the number of cases
were kept secret last December, while now
the figures are open to the public. Havana's
yellow-fever record last December and Jan-
uary was the largest in ten years, but it was
concealed. Now every one knows all about
the number of cases.

The fact is worthy of note that on the 20th
of last December Gen. Wood himself took
charge of the government of Cuba; and he
must therefore have given out the figures
for last December and January.
KENTUCKY AGAIN DELAYED.

Eve Post, 10. 26.00

We have already referred to President
Eliot's accusation that the Administra-
tion keeps the people ignorant of facts
which they have a right to know. This
policy of concealment is again evident
in Cuba. A few days ago word came
from the most trustworthy sources that
the yellow fever epidemic at Havana is
more severe than for a number of years.
When Gov. Wood, glad in the thought
that he was spreading health and happi-
ness through a hitherto misgoverned isl-
and, arrived in New York, he tried to
minimize the effect of the fever news by
saying that the death rate in Havana, in-
cluding yellow fever, is smaller than for
many years. Later, when the Washing-
ton correspondent of the New York Sun
pressed him for an explanation, he is re-
ported to have said:

“There is nothing new in the yellow-
fever epidemic. It is not as large as last
year, but the difference is that the number
of cases was kept secret last December,
while now the figures are open to the pub-
lic. Havana's yellow-fever record last De-
cember and January was the largest in
ten years, but it was concealed. Now every
one knows all about the number of cases.”

This admission of concealment had such
an unpleasant effect that Gov. Wood has-
tened last Wednesday, in an interview
with the correspondent of the Evening
Post, to explain the matter:

“He had never intended to intimate that
there had been an attempt to deceive the
public, but probably the subject had been
passed over, with the assent of the press
representatives, on account of the panicky
conditions of public feeling in the United
States.”

The distinction here is a subtle one--too
subtle for the crude intelligence of the
general public to grasp. There was, it
seems, neither concealment nor deceit,
but in order to prevent “panicky condi-
tions”--in short, in order to spread the
delusion that the administration of affairs
in Cuba was brilliantly successful--facts
were “passed over.” And now comes Gen.
Brooke--whom Gov. Wood succeeded on
December 20, 1899--with the blunt decla-
ration:

“Every [yellow fever] case was reported
immediately, and was made public at least
at the end of every month. Gen. Ludlow, as
Military Governor of Havana, was more di-
rectly connected with the matter than I. To
the best of my knowledge there was no con-
cealment, and fortunately very little yellow
fever. The small number of cases caused
the Cubans to believe that the Americans
would put an end to yellow fever in Cuba.”
At the moment there is a direct question
of veracity between Gen. Ludlow and
Gov. Wood. But even when that matter
is settled, we are compelled to believe
that important facts are “passed over.”
DEFENDING HIS RECORD.

Gen. Ludlow on the Failure to Publish
Yellow-Fever Reports.
[Special Dispatch to The Evening Post.]

WASHINGTON, October 26.--Gen. Ludlow,
who, as Governor of Havana, was directly
responsible for the publicity or non-publici-
ty of vital statistics of that city down to
about six months ago, after reading Gen.
Wood's recent interviews, said to your cor-
respondent this morning that there had nev-
er been any suppression or concealment of
last year's figures. He said:

The fullest measure of publicity was giv-
en to all sanitary data during my adminis-
tration and the reports day by day were
accessible to the press both in the depart-
ment headquarters and in the office of the
chief sanitary officer. In addition, every
month a tabulated statement was printed
and widely distributed, giving the complete
health statistics and sanitary data of the
preceding month. The press could use this
information at will. If it did not, it was for
some other reason than inability to procure
it. Possibly the official printing of the data
deprived them of the character of news.

The General added that there could have
been no motive for concealing or even ig-
noring these statistics, since the officers
concerned were proud of the good showing
they made.
